3.94.text:
When you think of bestselling
books, what titles come to mind?

9.02.text:
Perhaps The Lord of the Rings? It’s
sold 150 million copies worldwide,
which puts it in third place.

16.72.text: A Tale of Two Cities has sold 200 million copies.

20.40.text: That’s good enough for second place, but it’s still not the all-time best.

24.36.text:
The number one bestselling book in
all of history is the Bible.

28.96.text: In fact, the Bible has sold over five billion copies, and it’s been translated into more than two thousand languages.

36.74.text: The history of the Bible, and how it came to be the most widely distributed book in the world,

43.64.text:
The drama begins in antiquity, many
centuries before Christ.

47.76.text: The scribes, priests, prophets, and poets of the Hebrew people kept a record of their history with God,

53.98.text: along with their inspired insights and hopes.

56.22.text: Because these writings were a vital part of Hebrew life, they were carefully copied and recopied many times.

62.34.text: As time went on, these sacred writings were gathered into three collections known as

70.00.text: Eventually these three collections came to be considered the canon,

73.92.text: or official list, of the Hebrew Bible.

77.08.text: However, when Alexander the Great and his successors conquered the ancient world,

81.48.text: Greek became the common language of the people.

84.80.text: So in the third century B.C.E., the Hebrew Scriptures were translated

88.84.text:
into Greek for Jews and others
living outside of Palestine.

93.10.text:
This Greek translation was called
"the Septuagint."

96.02.text: It contained all the books of the Hebrew Bible, plus an extra seven books

100.30.text: not originally in the Hebrew collection, called the Apocrypha.

103.94.text: This was the Bible used by Jesus and the early church.

107.86.text:
Greek remained the common language
for hundreds of years,

110.52.text: so when the early Christians recorded the life of Jesus and the teachings of the Christian faith,

117.64.text: The earliest writings of the New Testament are the letters of the Apostle Paul.

121.68.text: He wrote to people in specific places, but other believers also wanted copies of Paul’s teachings,

127.22.text: so his letters began to circulate.

129.74.text: The Gospels soon followed, as well as other letters, exhortations, sermons, and writings.

135.46.text: Eventually, guided by the Spirit of God,

138.36.text: the church put together a collection that most accurately testified to Jesus Christ.

143.22.text: By the end of the fourth century, church councils reached a consensus,

146.88.text: and the canon of New Testament was officially recognized.

151.38.text:
Also in the fourth century, the
Emperor Constantine

154.45.text: authorized the creation of fifty copies of the complete Scriptures,

157.97.text: and possibly for the first time, the Old and the New Testaments came together as one book.

165.24.text: Almost as soon as the Bible was formed, scholars began translating it

169.14.text: into other languages for Christians living in other parts of the world.

172.84.text: It was important to the early church that as many people as possible had access to the Scriptures.

178.62.text: The most significant translation of the early church was a Latin version called the Vulgate.

184.22.text: A scholar named Jerome spent over twenty years living and studying in Palestine

189.42.text: in order to make an official translation of the Hebrew and Greek Scriptures into Latin.

194.66.text:
The Vulgate eventually became the
official text of western Christianity.

199.70.text:
However, the Latin-speaking Roman
Empire fell in the fifth century,

204.16.text:
and tribes such as the Vandals,
Goths, and Huns invaded Europe.

208.94.text: Christian monasteries began to collect biblical texts - especially Jerome’s Vulgate -

213.78.text: preserving and copying them throughout the centuries.

217.68.text: By this time missionaries and soldiers had brought the gospel to the British Isles,

222.30.text: and translated the Vulgate into the common language of the people.

226.46.text: But many rulers and church leaders felt that the Scriptures in the popular language

230.72.text: of the people challenged the Church’s authority.

233.88.text: Even though Latin had long-ceased to be the common language of the people,

237.46.text: it became a crime to possess or circulate non-Latin copies of the Bible.

242.68.text:
However, not all leaders felt the
same way.

246.42.text: In England, late in the fourteenth century, a churchman and political figure

250.68.text:
named John Wycliffe and his followers to
translated the Scriptures into the common language,

256.00.text: and it was completed the year Wycliffe died.

259.48.text:
The authorities did all they could
to suppress this English Bible,

262.84.text:
going so far as to dig up
Wycliffe’s body and burn it.

266.84.text: They banned the use of any new translation,

269.34.text: and many people were persecuted for copying or reading translated Scriptures.

274.44.text: In spite of this, the English people hungered to hear the biblical story in their own language.

279.84.text: But copies of the Bible had to be made by hand, so complete Bibles were scarce and very expensive...

285.96.text: until a printing breakthrough occurred in the middle of the fifteenth century.

290.18.text: In Germany, a goldsmith named Johann Gutenberg created the printing press,

295.22.text: allowing books to be printed on a machine rather than by hand or wood block.

299.50.text: The first large book produced by Gutenberg’s press was a Bible in Latin.

304.32.text: However, by the middle of the sixteenth century,

306.82.text: the Latin Bible had been translated and printed into 14 other languages.

311.00.text: It was around this time that a young scholar from England named William Tyndale came upon the scene.

317.02.text:
Sometimes called the Father
of the English Bible,

319.38.text:
Tyndale believed that people had the right
to read and hear the Scriptures in their own language.

324.60.text: He eventually went to Germany where he translated the New Testament from Greek into English,

329.40.text: and it became the first printed English New Testament.

333.80.text:
Copies were smuggled into England,
and secretly purchased and read.

337.92.text: Even though readers and owners were arrested, the Scriptures kept flowing in.

342.84.text: Tyndale went to Antwerp to work on a translation of the Old Testament, but before he had completed this work,

348.16.text:
he was betrayed, arrested, condemned a
heretic, and publicly executed.

353.24.text:
His last words reportedly were, "Lord,
open the King of England’s eyes!"

359.02.text:
Tyndale’s prayer was answered three
years later.

361.64.text: The first authorized Bible in the English language, called the Great Bible,

366.02.text: was published as the result of King Henry VIII’s injunction that an English Bible be placed in every parish.

372.84.text: People flocked to the churches to listen to the reading of the Scriptures in their own language.

378.02.text: Early in the seventeenth century, King James I authorized a new translation of the Scriptures.

383.80.text: This translation, known as the Authorized or King James Version, is still read today,

389.38.text: but it was only the beginning of English bible translation.

394.00.text: Since the Tyndale Bible there have been close to 900 English translations or paraphrases of the Bible.

400.62.text: This, coupled with versions in 2,000 other languages, makes the Bible

405.66.text: the most-read, most-translated, and bestselling book in history.

410.98.text: The fact that virtually anyone on earth can have the Scriptures in their own language

415.38.text: is due to the perseverance and sacrifice of those who never wavered from the belief

420.34.text:
that the Bible should be available
to anyone who wishes to read it.

424.36.text: However, that does not mean that every person on earth has open access to the Scriptures.

429.62.text: In some areas of the world today, the Bible continues to be seen as a revolutionary and dangerous book,

435.36.text: and its publication or distribution is either highly monitored or banned outright.

440.30.text: Many people can face persecution, imprisonment, or death for owning or teaching from the Bible.

447.88.text: Perhaps you wonder why this book is so popular that people would risk their lives to obtain one.

453.14.text: Those who do so believe that the Bible is more than simply a collection of stories or a book of history.

459.28.text: They understand it to be the very Word of God,

461.96.text: revealing his love, encouragement, and instruction to humanity.

466.52.text: There is something about the Bible that draws spiritually hungry people to its pages and nourishes them.

471.50.text:
As long as the desire for the
Scriptures remains,

474.48.text: there will be people - like Jerome, or Wycliffe, or Tyndale -

478.16.text: who are willing to dedicate their lives to bring God’s Word to you.

482.10.text: To obtain your own detailed copy of the Bible Explored: A Short History, or your own Bible,

487.28.text:
please contact the Canadian Bible
Society at biblesociety.ca.
